titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Received from the Cabinet Ministry their new project for a Treaty— Busy with it most of the afternoon— Evening at Count Panin’s. Played Casino with Madame de Grappendorf, Mlle: Otterstätt, and Mr: Engeström— Did not stay to supper.

2. Busily employed all day in making out a copy of the proposed Treaty— Mrs: Brown, Mrs: Sanford, & her Sisters to see Mrs: Adams— Half an hour at Dr: Brown’s in the Evening; being Margaret’s birth-day. Had a lesson of German in the morning— But at present I find no time to read.

3. Finished my Copy of the Treaty— Read a little of Bulow’s libel upon America— In the afternoon, the youngest Miss Bruhl, and two Miss Brown’s, with Mrs: Adams.— Passed a couple of hours at the Casino.

4. Lesson of German— Finished the translation of Gesner’s letter upon Landscape painting.— Wrote to the Cabinet Ministry; and to Mr: Murray.— Visit from Mr: Arbuthnot— Evening at the Swedish Minister’s, ball and supper.— Company large. Played Reversi with Madame de Hagen, Count Goltz & the Marquis de Musquiz. Did not stay to supper.

5. Dined with Mr: Grenville, who had a small company of Englishmen— Evening at Count Panin’s Play. The Theatre is very elegant, and holds between two and three hundred persons— They performed Les fausses infidelités,—le bon Ménage, and l’Avocat Patelin. The acting altogether was very good. Found letters from America, when I came home.

6. Had a visit this forenoon from the Abbé Denina, who came to enquire whether his Revolutions of Italy quoted in the Defence of the American Constitutions were from the original, or an English Translation. He told me he was acquainted with Coll: Smith here, and at the same time with Miranda— Called at half past twelve upon Count Finkenstein, and delivered him the copy of the Treaty in both languages ready to be drawn up.— At the Casino in the afternoon. Evening at home.

7. Letters this morning to Mr: Murray and Mr Bourne— Evening at the Play— Saw Die Verläumder, the Slanderers, a Comedy of Kotzebue in five Acts, a play brim full of Revolution, and apparently relished by the hearers on that account, and because the Satyre is pointed against the Austrian Government. Upon coming home, found Count and Countess Brühl and their daughters with Mrs: Adams.

8— Writing to my mother— Evening at Count Haugwitz’s— Whist with Madame de Heinitz, the Minister Baron Reck, and the Baron de Seckendorf— Did not stay to supper.— Mr: Arbuthnot paid us a visit in the afternoon.

9. Lesson from Mr: Catel— Wrote to the Secy: of State— Reading Bülow— Miss Neale with Mrs: Adams at tea— Passed the Evening at Bellevue— Played reversi with Countess Brühl, Madame de Riedesel and Count Degenfeld.

10. Wrote a couple of short Letters— Count & Countess Bruhl and their daughters Mrs: Brown & her family— Mr: and Mrs: Sanford and their Sisters, Miss Sophie Neale & Miss Dunderfeld, and Mr: Arbuthnot, at tea and the evening with us— Count Brühl says the Prussian Army is composed more than half of foreigners, about one fifth part is cavalry, and one twentieth Artillery.—

11— Lesson of German— Wrote to Mr: Garli Murray.— Mr: Garlike and Mr Richard both called on me to tell me the news of the french being beaten in Italy— At the play this Evening— Emilia Galotti performed. None of the actors played with sufficient warmth—and the last scene appears to me not well adapted to the stage.— Upon the whole deeply tragical as the play is, it is not affecting, and the total want of poetical Justice leaves us unsatisfied at the issue— The author intimates that the torment of a guilty conscience stimulated by the failure of the design upon which the crime was founded is the severest of all punishments— This may answer for the Prince, but it is hardly conceivable that such a character as Marinelli should have any conscience left.
12. Took a ride with Mrs: Adams, and afterwards a walk in the Park.— Reading Bülow in the afternoon; in the Evening spent a couple of hours at the Casino.

13. Translating Bülow’s preface.— Short walk before dinner— Wrote again in the afternoon, and took another walk. Evening at home— Met Mr: Hudelist under the Linden.— Finished reading Bülow, and began upon La Rochefoucauld Liancourt’s travels in the United States.

14. Lesson of German.— Upon looking over Bulow, met a quotation from Cicero, de Natura Deorum. compared it with the book and thus imperceptibly fell to reading Cicero, untill the whole morning was past. Mr: Schmidt, a man recommended to me by Count Brühl called upon me— As did Mr: Poirier from the widow Sittman.— Was at the play in the Evening, and saw Don Carlos, a Tragedy by Schiller, very complicated and very deep, as well as very long.— Upon going into the box, I found there a certain Monsr: de Trappe, and his niece, who for the second time reminded me of those unexpected and accidental meetings of old acquaintance, which are frequent in novels, and especially in that of Gil blas— I saw this Gentleman and Lady in June 1795—at the Hague, they were then going to America, and as I understood really embarked in July or August of that year from Amsterdam— In August 1797. as I was walking from St: James’s park into Spring-gardens at London, I met Mr: de Trappe and his niece arm in arm; going into the Park, but did not speak to them; and this Evening I found myself in the same box with them at the play.— What their intermediate adventures have been in utterly unknown to me; as I have never heard a word of them since they sailed or were to sail from Amsterdam from America. upon coming out of the play-house I met a little frenchman who asked me first, the way to the Linden; next whether I spoke french— Then whether I was of this Country or a Stranger, and lastly what Country I belonged to— All in two minutes.— I called at Dr: Brown’s for Mrs: Adams, who had spent the Evening there; but she was already gone home.

15. I have again commenced upon of those plans which I so frequently begin and never finish. The present would be of some utility, if I had the patience to carry it through; and of no great difficulty.— It requires great and persevering labour for some months, but nothing else.— Evening party at the Minister Arnim’s— Spoke to the Count Haugwitz concerning the affair of the Jew Bluch— He told me he had made his report to the king upon the subject of the Treaty, and that he expressed his satisfaction that the business was drawing so near to a conclusion agreeable on both parts.— Played Whist with a Mademoiselle de Hoeren, Count Wintzingerode, and an officer whom I did not know.
16. German lesson— All the morning engaged in writing.— Afternoon some time at the Casino— Mrs: Brown spent part of the Evening with Mrs: Adams.— My industrious fit draws towards its end.
17. Reading English newspapers, shortened my time for writing and of course my walk.— At the Casino, in the Evening, an hour— Purchased Wieland’s works and received some other books from the sale.

18. A bad cold, owing to our having ceased our fires— The weather still continues very chilly.— Long walk this afternoon in the rain. At the Casino, and a few minutes at Dr: Brown’s, where Mrs: Adams passed the Evening.

19. Employed as usual on the Sunday— Found however time for translating, though not so much as common.— Walk in the park.— Evening at Mr: Cohen’s private Comedy. L’avocat chausonnier, and Le barbier de Seville— The first very indifferent in itself.— The second pretty well acted excepting the part of Figaro;— no letters this Evening.

20. Write so much as to have little time for reading.— Walk twice in the park; before dinner and in the Evening. At the Casino— Mrs: Adams went with Mrs: Sanford to visit Madame de Voss.— Mrs: Schickler at tea.—

21. The annual review of the troops commenced this day— Mrs: Adams went with the Miss Browns: but my curiosity having been sufficiently gratified by what I saw last year, I did not go— Had a lesson from Mr: Catel. Rest of the day spent as usual— Walk towards Evening; and an hour at the Casino.

22. Reviews continued, but the rain this morning shortened it— Translating all day— Evening at the Ville de Paris, at Mrs: Sanfords: where were almost all the English in town; more than twenty persons, present. Lord Talbot, who is returned from his tour to Dresden and the archduke’s army; with Count St: George— Mr: Harris, a son of Lord Malmesbury— Colonel Stewart, Mr: Arbuthnot &c.

23. Last day of the reviews.— Mrs: Adams went— I did not— Lesson of German— Evening at the Ball given by the king at the palace— The king and queen both retired before supper.— Played reversi with Madame de Hagen, Count Bunau, and Count Goltz.

24. Got engaged this morning, in looking over the campaign of Buonaparte in Italy, which made it difficult to accomplish even the ordinary task of translation.— Was at the Casino, a short time in the Evening.

25. Lesson of German— Obliged to suspend almost the whole of this days translation to write Letters— Walk twice in the park. At the Casino, met the marquis of Castel-Alfieri, who has now had his audience of the king as Sardinian Minister.

26. Had more leisure than usual this day, and improved it for translation— Walk before dinner in the park, and towards evening with Mrs: Adams. Met Miss Emily Zennert who walked with us; an hour at the Casino.

27. My translations much interrupted by letter writing— Could of course read scarcely any thing. Walk twice in the park. Weather rainy and cold, the greatest part of the day.— At the Casino in the Evening, reading English reviews.
28. Still somewhat interrupted with letter writing.— Made up the loss by writing in the evening.— At the play. Saw Der Wildfang, an extravagant but comical farce of Kotzebue.— Could read nothing.

29. After the usual employment through the day, passed the evening and supped at Mr: Schickler’s with a large company. Mr: Schickler the father is has retired into the Country to live— Played whist with Baron de Seckendorf, Mr:and Mr: Fitch, an English-man.— Had likewise some music.

30. Mrs: Adams went with Mrs: Schickler and a party to Charlottenburg.— Was at the play, and saw Johanna von Monfaucon, a new comedy of Kotzebue; the most pleasing of all his plays that I have seen, because the least immoral.— It has likewise a number of fine situations, though nothing very original— Walking after the play, met Mr: Arbuthnot.
31. Walk twice in the park, before dinner and in the Evening. Wrote as much as usual. Spent an hour at the Casino— Met Baron Rothkirch, who told me he was going to England, and perhaps to America.

Day. There are now scarcely circumstances sufficient occurring usually to distinguish one day from another. Rise between 6 and 7. Study German or take a lesson of it till 10. Breakfast— write letters or translate, till almost 3. Walk, half an hour: dine— translate again or read till 7. Walk an hour and spend another at the Casino.— Home between 9 and 10. Sup— Play piquet half an hour with Mrs: Adams, and retire to bed.
